chapter.pericope: Judgment against the Leaders of Ephraim

ul.li1: 1Ah! The garland of the pride of the drunkards of Ephraim
ul.li2: and the withering flower of the glory of his beauty,
ul.li1: which is at the head of the rich valley,Literally “a valley of fat”
ul.li2: ones overcomeLiterally “ones struck” with wine!
ul.li1: 2Look! The Lord has a mighty and strong one,
ul.li2: like a rainstorm of hail, a wind storm of destruction,
like a rainstorm of mighty overflowing waters,
ul.li1: he will put them to the earth with his hand.
3The garland of the pride of the drunkards of Ephraim
ul.li2: will be trampledThe Hebrew is plural by feet,
ul.li1: 4and the withering flower of the glory of its beauty
ul.li2: which is at the head of the rich valleyLiterally “a valley of fat”
ul.li1: will be like its early fig before summer,
ul.li2: which the one who sees it swallowsLiterally “Which, when the one who sees it sees it, he swallows it” while it is still in his hand.
ul.li1: 5In that day, Yahweh of hosts will become a garland of glory
ul.li2: and a diadem of beauty to the remnant of his people,
ul.li1: 6and a spirit of justice to the one who sits over judgment,
ul.li2: and strength to those who turn back the battle at the gate.
ul.li1: 7And these also stagger because of wine
ul.li2: and stagger because of strong drink;
ul.li1: priest and prophet stagger because of strong drink;
ul.li2: they are confusedOr “swallowed” because of wine.
ul.li1: They stagger because of strong drink;
ul.li2: they err in vision.
ul.li1: They stagger in the rendering of a decision,
ul.li2: 8for all the tables are full of disgusting vomit, with no place left.Literally “without a place”
ul.li1: 9To whom will he teach knowledge,
ul.li2: and to whom will he explain the message?
ul.li1: Those who are weaned from milk,
ul.li2: those taken from the breast?
ul.li1: 10For it is blah-blah upon blah-blah,
ul.li2: blah-blah upon blah-blah,
ul.li1: gah-gah upon gah-gah,
ul.li2: gah-gah upon gah-gah,In this context, the Hebrew expressions tsaw-tsaw and qaw-qaw are likely meant to sound like baby talk, but they could mean “command upon command” and “rule upon rule”
ul.li1: a little here, a little there.

chapter.p: 11For he will speak with stammeringLiterally “stammer of lip” and another tongue to this people, 12to whom he has said,

ul.li1: “This is rest; give rest to the weary;
ul.li2: and this is repose”; yetOr “and” they were not willing to hear.

chapter.p: 13And to them the word of Yahweh will be

ul.li1: blah-blah upon blah-blah
ul.li2: blah-blah upon blah-blah
ul.li1: gah-gah upon gah-gah
ul.li2: gah-gah upon gah-gah,In this context, the Hebrew expressions tsaw-tsaw and qaw-qaw are likely meant to sound like baby talk, but they could mean “command upon command” and “rule upon rule”
ul.li1: a little here, a little there,
so that they may go and stumble backward
ul.li2: and be broken and ensnared and captured.

ul.li1: 14Therefore hear the word of Yahweh, men of mockery,
ul.li2: rulers of these people in Jerusalem:

ul.li1: “We have madeLiterally “cut” a covenant with death,
ul.li2: and we have made an agreement with Sheol.

chapter.p: The overwhelming flood, when it passes through, will not come to us,

ul.li1: for we have made liesHebrew “lie” our refuge,
and we have hidden ourselves in falsehood.”
“Look! I am laying a stone in Zion,
ul.li2: a testedLiterally “testing” stone,
ul.li1: a precious cornerstone,
ul.li2: a founded foundation:

chapter.p: ‘The one who trusts will not panic.’Literally “hurry”

ul.li1: 17And I will make justice the measuring line,
ul.li2: and righteousness the plumb line;
ul.li1: and hail will sweep away the refuge of lies,Hebrew “lie”
ul.li2: and waters will flood over the hiding place.
ul.li1: 18And your covenant with death will be annulled,
ul.li2: and your agreement with Sheol will not stand;
ul.li1: you will become a trampling place for the overwhelming flood when it passes through.
ul.li2: 19As often as it passes through,Literally “From enough his passing through” it will take you,
ul.li1: for morning by morningLiterally “in the morning in the morning” it will pass through,
ul.li2: in the day and in the night,

chapter.p: and understanding the message will be only terror.”

ul.li1: 20For the bed is too short to stretch out on,Literally “from stretching oneself”
ul.li2: and the covering is too narrow when wrapping oneself.
ul.li1: 21For Yahweh will rise up as at Mount Perazim;
ul.li2: he will rave as in the valley at Gibeon
ul.li1: to do his deed—his deed is strange—
ul.li2: and to work his work—his work is alien!
ul.li1: 22And now you must not scoff,
ul.li2: or your bonds will be strong,

chapter.p: for I have heard from the Lord, Yahweh of hosts:

ul.li1: complete destruction
ul.li2: decreed upon all the land.

ul.li1: 23Listen, and hear my voice!
ul.li2: Listen attentively, and hear my word!
ul.li1: 24Is it all day that the plowman plows,
ul.li2: opens to sow seed, harrows his ground?
ul.li1: 25When he has leveled its surface,Literally “face” does he not scatter dill,
ul.li2: and sow cumin seed,
and plantLiterally “place” wheat in planted rows,Hebrew “row”
and barley in an appointed place,
and spelt grain as its border?
ul.li1: 26And his God instructs him about the prescription;That is, “the proper way”
ul.li2: he teaches him.
ul.li1: 27For dill is not threshed with a threshing sledge,
ul.li2: nor is a wheel of a utility cart rolledLiterally “turned” over cumin,
ul.li1: but dill is beaten out with a stick,
ul.li2: and cumin with a rod.
ul.li1: 28Grain is crushed fine,
ul.li2: but certainly one does not thresh it forever;
ul.li1: and one drives the wheel of his cart,
ul.li2: but his horses do not crush it.

chapter.p: 29This also comes forth from Yahweh of hosts.

ul.li1: He is wonderful in advice;
ul.li2: he makes great wisdom.
